statement:
An algebraic set over an uncountably infinite base field $\mathbb{F}$
(like the real or complex numbers) cannot be countably infinite.

Proof: Let $S$ be a countably infinite subset of $\mathbb{F}^n$. By a
cardinality argument (see the attachment), there must exist a line such
that the projection of this set to the line is infinite. Since the
projection of an algebraic set to a linear subspace is an algebraic set,
the projection of $S$ to this line would be an algebraic subset of the
line. However, an algebraic subset of a line is the locus of zeros of
some polynomial, hence must be finite. Therefore, $S$ could not be
algebraic since that would lead to a contradiction.
